name: Distribution Game
description: Test your knowledge of probability distributions

scenarios.description: In a factory, we're counting the number of defective products in batches of 100 items. The probability of each item being defective is constant.
scenarios.explanation: This is a Binomial distribution because we have a fixed number of trials (100 items) and each trial has the same probability of success (being defective).

scenarios.description: Counting the number of customers arriving at a store in 1-hour intervals. The average rate is constant.
scenarios.explanation: This follows a Poisson distribution as we're counting rare events (customer arrivals) in a fixed interval with a constant average rate.

scenarios.description: Number of traffic accidents per day in a large city.
scenarios.explanation: This follows a Poisson distribution as accidents are rare events occurring in a fixed time interval.

scenarios.description: Flipping a coin 10 times and counting the number of heads.
scenarios.explanation: This is a Binomial distribution with 10 trials and probability 0.5 for each trial.

scenarios.description: Number of successful sales in 20 independent attempts, where each sale has a 30% chance of success.
scenarios.explanation: This is a Binomial distribution with 20 trials and probability 0.3 for each trial.

scenarios.description: Average number of typing errors per page in a long document.
scenarios.explanation: This follows a Poisson distribution as typing errors are rare events occurring in a fixed space (page).

scenarios.description: Number of calls received per minute in a call center.
scenarios.explanation: This follows a Poisson distribution as calls arrive randomly with a constant average rate.

scenarios.description: In a dice game, number of times a 6 appears in 12 rolls.
scenarios.explanation: This is a Binomial distribution with 12 trials and probability 1/6 for each trial.

scenarios.description: Number of genetic mutations in a specific DNA segment.
scenarios.explanation: This follows a Poisson distribution as mutations are rare events occurring in a fixed space segment.

scenarios.description: Average height of university students, assuming a symmetric distribution around the mean.
scenarios.explanation: Height typically follows a Normal distribution as it's a continuous variable with symmetric variation around a mean.

scenarios.description: Weight of newborns in a hospital, known to follow a symmetric distribution.
scenarios.explanation: Birth weights typically follow a Normal distribution as they're continuous and roughly symmetric around the mean.

scenarios.description: IQ test scores, with mean 100 and standard deviation 15.
scenarios.explanation: IQ scores are designed to follow a Normal distribution with mean 100 and standard deviation 15.

scenarios.description: Useful life of LED bulbs, assuming symmetric variability around the mean.
scenarios.explanation: Product lifetimes often follow a Normal distribution when the failure mode is wear and tear.

scenarios.description: Blood pressure measurements in a healthy adult population.
scenarios.explanation: Blood pressure typically follows a Normal distribution in a homogeneous population.

scenarios.description: Number of goals scored by a soccer team in a game.
scenarios.explanation: Goals in soccer are relatively rare events occurring in a fixed time interval.
